segments.text: Om Agyana Timiraandasya Gyananjanishalakaya Chaksharunmilitam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
Nama Om Vishnupadaya Krishna Preshthaya Bhutale Shreemate Bhaktivedanta Swamin Nithinamine

Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare

Devim Saraswateem Vyasam Tato Jayam Udi Rayet
In this session, we will be discussing from the 17th verse of the 6th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.
Prema Atibhara Nirbhinna Pulaka Ango Ati Nirvrata
Ananda Samplave Leeno Na Apashyam Ubhayam Mune
The meaning of this verse is O Vyasa Deva

Radha Muni is speaking to Vyasa Deva, describing the experience he underwent in his previous life when he was instructed by the Bhaktivedantas and he went to a secluded place, a sacred spot in the Himalayas and he sat there firmly and began to do meditation.
So, we have heard so far how he experienced symptoms of ecstasy.
So, what does it mean to ecstasy?
One of the symptoms is described in the 16th verse, that tears started rolling down from his eyes.
What else happened?
That is being described in this verse.
O Vyasa Deva, at that time, being exceedingly overpowered by feelings of happiness,
every part of my body became separately enlivened.
Being absorbed in an ocean of ecstasy, I could not see both myself and the Lord.
This is the 17th verse.
I just read the translation of the 17th verse.
If you remember, in the 16th verse, Narada Muni had told, he experienced that joy, the ecstasy of having come to the stage of that bhava.
Bhava nirjita chetasa and tears began to flow from his eyes, tears of joy, extreme joy and he also had mentioned the Supreme Lord appeared on the lotus of his heart.
Krishna, who is seated on the heart, gave him darshan.
Gave him darshan.
Next, what?
He experienced, Narada experienced, that he is overpowered by feelings of happiness, exceedingly overpowered.
That means the happiness is so much, there is no comparison to any material experience of happiness at all.
It is completely different.
This is the first point.
Srila Prabhupada says in the parport,
Spiritual feelings of happiness and intense ecstasies have no mundane comparison.
There is no comparison with anything material that we experience in this world.
There is no material comparison.
This is entirely a different experience.
It is incomparable because,
the amount of joy one experiences is actually unlimited.
Though we are very, very tiny and our experience has got limitation, but still, to the extent we can experience as much joy as we really can,
it is possible to experience as much joy as we really can.
It is possible by spiritual practice of Bhakti, Sadhana Bhakti, through the stages, as I mentioned in the previous session,
Shraddha, Sadhu Sangha, Bhajana Kriya, Anartha Nivritti, Nishtha, Ruchi, Asakti, Bhava.
In that Bhava stage, the eighth stage, one stage before Prema, one stage before the ultimate perfection.
In that Bhava stage, the eighth stage, one stage before Prema, one stage before the ultimate perfection.
In that Bhava stage, the eighth stage, one stage before Prema, one step before the ultimate perfection.
In that stage, one is exceedingly overpowered by feelings of happiness.
So, there is no mundane comparison.
Therefore, it is very difficult to give expression to such feelings.
We can just have a glimpse, as far as we are concerned, we are beginners,
how we have got to make progress.
It will take time.
We have to become serious.
We have to apply the principles.
We have to follow all the rules, regulations.
We have to associate with devotees.
We have to give up all misconceptions that we have about ourselves, or God, or the relationship, or about this world.
Everything we have to.
We have to purify our heart.
We have to purify our consciousness.
So, we can get an idea in the words of Narada, as he is describing to Vyasa Deva.
In the words of Narada, we can get a brief glimpse of the ecstasy that Narada Muni experienced
by reaching that eighth stage.
Reaching that eighth stage of progress in the practice of Bhakti.
